issues.description: The problem statement requires a static method named acceptSupplyDelivery(String, int, int) on SealSaloon (see UML and explicit text). The solution implementation provides a static method with equivalent behavior but a different name: receiveDelivery(String, int, int). This name/signature mismatch between the specification and the solution will confuse students and (if tests expect acceptSupplyDelivery) make it impossible to match the required API.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the solution use the exact method name and signature required by the problem: rename receiveDelivery to public static void acceptSupplyDelivery(String name, int price, int quantity). Alternatively, update the problem statement/UML to use receiveDelivery if that name is intended; keep names consistent across spec, template, and solution.

issues.description: The problem statement tells students to initialize the SealSaloon attributes (orders and the final stock) in the no-argument constructor, but elsewhere explicitly requires that the stock attribute be static (shared across instances). Initializing a static field in an instance constructor is contradictory: a static field is normally initialized at declaration or in a static initializer, not per-instance in the constructor. This internal contradiction in the specification can confuse students about where/how to initialize the static stock field.
issues.suggested_fix: Clarify the initialization guidance in the problem statement. Either (A) require stock to be an instance final field and initialize it in the constructor, or (B) require stock to be static (shared) and instruct students to initialize it at declaration (or in a static initializer). For example: "Initialize orders in the no-arg constructor. Declare stock as static final and initialize it at its declaration (or in a static initializer) since it is shared across all SealSaloon instances."

issues.description: The problem statement requires a static method named acceptSupplyDelivery(String, int, int) on SealSaloon to handle incoming ingredient deliveries, but the solution implementation provides a static method named receiveDelivery(String, int, int) instead. These two names refer to the same conceptual operation (accepting a supply delivery) but are different identifiers across artifacts, which can confuse students (they will look for acceptSupplyDelivery as specified in the task) and may break automated checks that expect the problem-specified name.
issues.suggested_fix: Use a single consistent name for the delivery method across artifacts. Either rename the solution method receiveDelivery(...) to acceptSupplyDelivery(...) (maintaining the same signature and static behavior), or update the problem statement and tests to accept receiveDelivery(...). Renaming the solution method to acceptSupplyDelivery is recommended to match the exercise specification.
